nodes.bodyText: Not sure if the extension of the TransactionContext is valuable here. A abstract class definition with the currentTimeMicros would be sufficient for the benchmark. Or even just define the two different methods directly without any classes at all

Btw:
 * The clock implementation provided here is based on the same underlying clock
 * as {@link System#currentTimeMillis()}, but may have a precision finer than
 * milliseconds if available.
 * However, little to no guarantee is provided about the accuracy of the
 * underlying clock. Applications requiring a more accurate clock must implement
 * this abstract class themselves using a different external clock, such as an
 * NTP server.

I think we've to mention this in some way

nodes.bodyText:
Reading this again I think the Therefore, ... implies that the prior sentence explains the behavior of the same time value is returned for every invocation within a single statement. but there is no logical correlation between the two.
The first statement would actually imply that there could be different values.
I think this should be rephrased a bit to instead point out that the clock time is looked up at most once within the scope of a single query to ensure multiple current_time occurences evaluate to the same value.
